Surisitee’s Sporting Goods Store sells Good Y in a perfectly competitive market with a downward-sloping demand curve and an upward-sloping supply curve. The market price is <math alttext="$40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> per unit.

(a) Calculate the average fixed cost of producing <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units. Show your work.

(b) Identify the profit-maximizing quantity. Explain using marginal analysis.

(c) Calculate the economic profit at the profit-maximizing quantity you identified in part (b). Show your work.

(d) Based on your answer to part (c), will the number of firms in the industry increase, decrease, or stay the same in the long run? Explain.

(e) Based on your answer to part (c), will the market price increase, decrease, or stay the same in the long run? Explain.

(f) The income elasticity of demand for Good Y is <math alttext="negative 2.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the cross-price elasticity of demand for basketballs with respect to the price of Good Y is <math alttext="negative 0.8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on your answer to part (e), what will happen to the demand for basketballs? Explain.

(g) Now assume that the market in which Surisitee’s Sporting Goods Store operates is in long-run equilibrium.(i) Suppose the rent paid by Surisitee’s Sporting Goods Store increases. Will Surisitee’s Sporting Goods Store’s profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y increase, decrease, or stay the same in the short run? Explain.(ii) Instead suppose Surisitee’s Sporting Goods Store hires labor in a perfectly competitive market and the market wage decreases. Will Surisitee’s Sporting Goods Store’s profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y increase, decrease, or stay the same in the short run? Explain.
